perturbation.original_text: 1.1. AFFILIATE shall mean, when used with reference to a party, any individual or entity directly or indirectly controlling, controlled by or under common control with such party. For purposes of this definition, "control" means the direct or indirect ownership of at least 50% of the outstanding voting securities of a party, or the right to control the policy decisions of such party.
perturbation.changed_text: 1.1. AFFILIATE shall mean, when used with reference to a party, any individual or entity directly or indirectly controlling, controlled by or under common control with such party. For purposes of this definition, "control" constitutes the direct or indirect influence over the operational decisions of a party.
perturbation.explanation: The original text defines "control" as ownership of at least 50% of voting securities or the right to control policy decisions. The modified text changes the definition of "control" to "influence over operational decisions." This introduces an internal contradiction because "control" now has two different definitions within the same contract, leading to uncertainty. One could argue ownership is required, while another interpretation would allow for operational influence as fulfilling the definition of control.

perturbation.original_text:
1.22. USER shall mean a single person who accesses and views a Site whether directly from a web browser or through a Link.

1.23. USER DATA shall mean all data generated by an Internet server that relates to file requests, user identification, transaction logs, session times and other information regarding the Users generated or collected by or through a Co-Branded Site, but excluding any information that relates or refers to a particular project of such User.
perturbation.changed_text:
1.22. USER shall mean a person or automated system that accesses and views a Site whether directly from a web browser or other means.

1.23. USER DATA shall mean all data generated by an Internet server that relates to file requests, visitor identification, session metrics, engagement duration, and related information pertaining to the users managed by the Co-Branded Site. Specific project details will be included.
perturbation.explanation: The original 'USER' definition refers to a single person, whereas the modified version includes 'automated system.' The original text excludes information about a particular project of the User, while the modified version explicitly includes it. These changes create conflicting data privacy and usage obligations.

perturbation.original_text:
1.  DEFINITIONS
1.12. INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY shall mean any and all trade secrets, patents, copyrights, trademarks, service marks, URLs, trade dress, brand features, know-how and similar rights of any type under the laws of any applicable governmental authority, including, without limitation, all applications and registrations relating to any of the foregoing.

1.13. INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY RIGHTS shall mean all rights in and to Intellectual Property, including, without limitation, all patent rights, copyrights, trademarks, service marks, know-how and trade secrets.
perturbation.changed_text:
1.  DEFINITIONS
1.12. INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY shall mean tangible inventions, designs, and other physical creations protected under patent, copyright, and industrial design laws.

1.13. INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY RIGHTS shall mean all rights in and to Intellectual Property, limited to patents and registered copyrights.
perturbation.explanation: The original definition of 'INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY' is broad, encompassing various types of intellectual creations. In contrast, the modified definition limits it to tangible inventions and designs. Similarly, 'INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY RIGHTS' originally covered a wide range of rights, while the revision focuses solely on rights related to patents and registered copyrights. These changes generate contradiction and raise ambiguities in the agreement, leading to confusion regarding the extent of protection covered. For example, trade secrets might no longer be considered 'INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY', leading to complications in enforcement.
